name: milk production, from cow | cow milk | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20999/documentation

This dataset represents the production of average milk from dairy cows in South Africa. The activity includes the consumption of feed, the production of feed (silage) and pasture where this is produced on site, the operation of cattle housing systems for the management of the dairy herd and the production of cow milk. The functional unit is 1 kg of Fat and Protein Corrected Milk (FPCM) raw milk from dairy farms. The FPCM correction is made for a conversion to a 4.0% fat and 3.3% true protein content, following the equation provided by the International Dairy Federation (IDF): FPCM (kg/yr) = Production (kg/yr) x [0.1226 x Fat% + 0.0776 x Protein% + 0.2534]. Live animals sold for slaughter (cull cows - cows slaughtered when no longer productive - and male calves) are by-products of the milk system, as are  solid and liquid manure.;This dataset does not cover organic milk production.;Pasture-based system: 90% of manure is generated on pasture during grazing and is thus not collected, with the remaining 10% collected in slurry and stored prior to treatment. Total-mixed ration (TMR) system: 35% of manure is generated on pasture during grazing and is thus not collected, about 44% of the manure is managed as solid manure and the remainder is managed as liquid manure. 

This activity starts from the reception and storage of feed materials, and dairy herd housing.

This activity ends with the provision of milk at the farm gate, ready for delivery. The dataset includes the consumption of feed; the production of pasture and feed (sliage) taking place on-site; the livestock management operations (including bedding, drinking water, milking equipment, cleaning products and water), methane emissions from enteric fermentation and manure management emissions (methane, ammonia and nitrous oxide); emissions from the application of synthetic fertilisers in pasture and silage production (ammonia, nitrous oxide, nitrates and phosphates); energy and buildings (including electricity used in cattle housing and milk parlour equipment, and diesel for regular operations). The dataset does not include fodder and feed production and processing into meal for animals where this takes place off site; nor milk transportation beyond the farm gate (e.g. to dairy processing plants). The dataset does not include the emissions associated with using the manure as a fertiliser on the farms (this is because manure is modelled as a by-product in the ecoinvent datasets, even though it is used in the growing of pasture in most South African dairy operations). Also, the dataset does not include particulate matter emissions, nor any drugs used on the dairy farm.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/014:Animal production/0141:Raising of cattle and buffaloes

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The production volume data are from Milk Producers Organisation (MPO)  data for 2016. 2016 is therefore taken as the reference year. National herd statistics and dependent emissions (methane and nitrous oxide) are from the latest national GHG inventory (2012), whilst farm data is circa 2010.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: South African values: not applicable worldwide. The dairy system is South Africa is modelled as 48% of milk produced via total-mixed ration (TMR) intensive production systems and 52% produced via pasture-based systems.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Data and assumptions are intended to reflect current equipment, processes, and market conditions.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: The inventory data is primarily from five farms in the Western Cape for the 2008/2009 production year, and supplemented with data from literature and expert knowledge, where necessary. The Western Cape is responsible for about 27% of the total milk produced in South Africa, second only to the Eastern Cape in 2014 (DAFF, 2015b). The coastal areas in South Africa, including the Western Cape itself, accounted for 82% of the total production due to the more suitable climate for dairy farming, with mild temperatures and good rainfall ensuring good quality natural and artificial pastures (DAFF, 2015b). Although the sample size is small, the five farms represent a reasonable cross section of farming practices in the Western Cape which encompass different farming approaches (i.e. intensive stall based systems and pasture based systems), a range in farm sizes and a range of geographical areas within the Western Cape Province. Academic publications (Banga et al., 2014, Du Toit et al., 2013) provided further information, such as that on enteric fermentation, conception rates, culling practices etc. Emissions from the agricultural process estimated according to Nemecek and Schnetzer (2011) and other references cited where appropriate.   Reference(s): DAFF (2015) A profile of the South African dairy market value chain 2015. Available at: http://www.nda.agric.za/doaDev/sideMenu/Marketing/Annual%20Publications/Commodity%20Profiles/field%20crops/Dairy%20market%20value%20chain%20profile%202015.pdf; du Toit C.J.L., Meissner H.H. and van Niekerk W.A. (2013) Direct Methane and Nitrous Oxide Emissions of South African Dairy and Beef Cattle, South African Journal of Animal Science, Volume 43 (3), pp 320-339.; Nemecek and Schnetzer (2011) Methods of Assessment of Direct Field Emissions for LCIs of Agricultural Production Systems, Life cycle inventories of Swiss and European agricultural production systems; IPCC (2006). IPCC Guidelines for national greenhouse gas inventoriesâ€š Prepared by the National Greenhouse Gas Inventories Programme.

exchanges.description: kg of Fat and Protein Corrected Milk. FPCM is 4.0% fat and 3.3% true protein content. Conversion to FPCM is as follow, according to the International Dairy Federation: FPCM (kg/yr) = Production (kg/yr) x [0.1226 x Fat% + 0.0776 x Protein% + 0.2534]. Raw milk density: 1031 kg/m3

exchanges.description: Solid manure generated excluding that left on pasture during grazing (60% of total manure). Calculated from number of animals and a manure generation rate of 7.7 tonnes/(head.year) for dairy cattle, based on the manure generated in pens and total heads of dairy in South Africa (DEA, 2017). These figures are based on manure management practices at representative operations in the region for intensive and pasture based operations. Reference(s): DEA (2017) Unlocking Barriers and Opportunities for Land-use Based Climate-Change Mitigation Activities in South Africa, Department of Environmental Affairs of South Africa, Available at: https://www.environment.gov.za/sites/default/files/reports/unlockingbarriers_land-usebasedclimatechangemitigation.pdf. (Accessed September 2017).

exchanges.description: Ammonia emissions due to volatilisation from manure management are estimated at 21 and 10 kg NH3 per head per year for milking cows and heifers, respectively, using the Tier 2 methodology of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) with factors for tropical production systems. Ammonia emissions from synthetic fertiliser application is estimated at 1.02 tonnes N2O per year and is very farm specific depending on the degree of cultivated pasture and fertiliser applied. Range across five farms is from zero to 6.9 tonnes NH3 per year, calculated using farm-specific fertiliser application rates and with emissions estimated using the Tier 2 methodology of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).

exchanges.description: Methane emissions from enteric fermentation from lactating cows, heifers ad calves, and from manure management. Value is from Du Toit et al. (2013) for the national dairy herd across all age groups (cattle numbers for 2010). The values of Du Toit et al (2013) are used as they are representative of South African dairy production as a whole and are applied in South Africa's national GHG reporting. Direct methane emissions for South African dairy cattle are estimated using the Tier 2 methodology of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), but adapted for tropical production systems. Full details available in the publication: du Toit C.J.L., Meissner H.H. and van Niekerk W.A. (2013) Direct Methane and Nitrous Oxide Emissions of South African Dairy and Beef Cattle, South African Journal of Animal Science, Volume 43 (3), pp 320-339.

flow.name: Methane, non-fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Direct and indirect emissions from manure management are estimated at 0.22 and 0.61 kg N2O per head per year, respectively, using the Tier 2 methodology of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) with factors for tropical production systems. Value is from Du Toit et al. (2013) for the national dairy herd across all age groups (cattle numbers for 2010). Direct and indirect nitrous oxide emissions from synthetic fertiliser application is estimated at 3.3 tonnes NH3 per year and is very farm specific depending on the degree of cultivated pasture and fertiliser applied. Range across five farms is from zero to 6.9 tonnes NH3 per year, calculated using farm-specific fertiliser application rates and with emissions estimated using the Tier 2 methodology of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). Reference: du Toit C.J.L., Meissner H.H. and van Niekerk W.A. (2013) Direct Methane and Nitrous Oxide Emissions of South African Dairy and Beef Cattle, South African Journal of Animal Science, Volume 43 (3), pp 320-339.

flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Generic value taken from ecoinvent dataset  "milk production, from cow, GLO" (i.e. not specific to South Africa). Comment from "milk production, from cow, GLO": 650 kg dried wood chips (wet mass) per dairy cow per year is used for animal litter. Sawdust may also be used. The division by 1.4 is to add up to the wet mass of the exchange.
